awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019: Ecology and evolution of a rare phenomenon: structural color in fruits
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Fruit color plays an essential role in the life cycle of many plants by attracting animals who eat the fruits and carry the seeds away from the parent plant. Blue fruits are relatively rare, and some produce vivid colors without the use of pigments. They accomplish this via nano-scale structures in their cell walls that interfere with light to produce color. This research will identify new species that exhibit such structurally colored fruits, and describe the bio-physical mechanisms responsible for these colors. In addition, this work will examine the evolution of structural color in fruits from a group of trees native to Australia, the Indo-Pacific, and Southeast Asia. The project will inform our understanding of the evolution of rare traits (such as blue fruit color) as well as provide a platform for multi-disciplinary interaction between biologists, physicists, and material scientists. In addition, this work will provide training for the fellow and undergraduates who will be involved in the work. The project's findings will be disseminated through scholarly publications and conferences as well as to the public via outreach activities.

The paucity of known structurally colored fruits has limited hypotheses about the ecological function of structural color in fruits and the circumstances behind its evolution. Northeast Australia has a relatively high number of blue-fruited species, including two of the known structurally colored fruits, E. angustifolius and Delarbrea michieana. The fellow will rely on both herbarium and living collections in botanical gardens to 1) survey herbarium collections for new species that may exhibit structural color, 2) describe the biophysical mechanism behind structural color in new species using optical and transmission electron microscopy, and 3) test the hypothesis that structural color serves as an honest signal of high nutritional reward in Elaeocarpus using phylogenetic comparative methods. The fellow will quantify a variety of color, nutritional content, morphological traits, and cell wall nanostructures across Elaeocarpus. She will collaborate with an interdisciplinary team at the University of Colorado-Boulder and the University of Cambridge, train biology and physics undergrads, and participate in science outreach activities in both locations. The research has the potential for bioinspired and biomimetic engineering applications, and will improve our understanding of the origin, evolution, and ecology of rare structural colors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the evolution of a rare trait in fruits, the use of structural color.  Although most plants use pigments to produce their colors, some plants use nanostructures that are small enough to interfere with light and which can create color from transparent materials. Prior to this project, only four species were known to produce structural colors in their fruits, most of which used cellulose to build their nanostructures.  In this project, we identified an additional nine species that all use lipids, organized into many layers, to reflect blue light.  This mechanism to create color is very rare and, thus far, only found in fruits.

We traced the evolution of this trait in several groups of plants, including Viburnum, Elaeocarpus, and the Lantaneae. In some of these groups, we found an association between color and nutritional content, but in other groups that same association did not occur.  We speculate that the reason for this difference depends on which kinds of lipids the groups are using: a species that evolved structural color using digestible lipids is much more likely to associate color with nutrition than a species that used indigestible waxes.  The identification of so many more species that use structural colors to make their fruits blue, and the fact that they use very similar structures made of lipids, opens the door to testing the ecological significance of such colors.

In conjunction with the study of structural colors, we also dove into some of the other factors that influence the evolution of fruit colors. For instance, we began to look at correlated evolution of flower and fruit traits. Fruits develop directly from flowers, yet we know very little about how these different organs influence each others’ ecology and evolution. More recently, we have begun to look at the relationship between metal accumulation and color in fruits, as accumulating aluminum can alter the color the of the fruit depending on the pigment being used.

Ultimately, our collective understanding of why and how fruit color evolves is limited, but these projects have begun to shed light on new factors that can either serve as case studies to better understand plant-animal interactions, or have identified factors that influence fruit coloration on a large scale. Although the animals that consume fruits are undoubtedly important, they are not the only important factor.  As part of this work, I supervised or was involved in supervising numerous undergraduate students, and several masters and PhD students, and presented some of the results at various stakeholder meetings (ranging from international conferences to local meetings focused on particular habitats).
